coredata.dc:title: A novel polymer electrolyte membrane for application in solid state lithium metal battery
coredata.dc:creator: Zewde, Berhanu W.
Carbone, Lorenzo
Greenbaum, Steve
Hassoun, Jusef
coredata.dc:description: Polyethylene oxide (PEO), dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) and lithium trifluoromethanesulfonate (LiCF3SO3) salts are combined into a composite polymer electrolyte studied for application in lithium metal battery. FTIR measurements and AFM images are used to reveal the structure and morphology of the polymer electrolyte, while electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), chronoamperometry and voltammetry are employed for determining the electrolyte conductivity, lithium transference number, chemical and electrochemical stability, respectively. The data reveal a suitable conductivity and lithium transport, i.e., δ above 10−4 Scm−1 and tLi + about 0.5, at moderate temperature, which allow the use of the membrane and a LiFePO4 olivine cathode in an efficient lithium metal cell delivering a capacity of 130mAhg−1 at about 3.4V, and operating at 50°C. This relatively low operating temperature, the good electrochemical properties, and the polymer configuration of the PEO-DMSO-LiCF3SO3 membrane suggest it as a viable solution for application in high energy lithium metal battery.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Polyethylene oxide (PEO)
Dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO)
Lithium-metal
Battery

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Photographic image of the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO solid polymer electrolyte membrane. See Experimental section for sample identification.

FTIR absorbance spectra of A) PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane, the PEO20LiCF3SO3 and DMSO blank at increasing wave number. B) The magnified spectra at different range of wave numbers. See Experimental section for sample identification.
Atomic Force Microscopy (AFM) images of (A) PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO (B) PEO20LiCF3SO3. See Experimental section for sample identification.

Conductivity Arrhenius plots of PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane during cooling (A) and heating (B) treatment. Steady state conductivities of the PEO20LiCF3SO3 blank are indicated by stars in each panel. Impedance measurement performed in a 0.5MHz–0.1Hz frequency range, signal amplitude 10mV, data collected every 5° (every 2° near by the transition temperature).

Electrochemical characteristics of PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO electrolyte. (A) Interface stability in a Li/Li symmetrical cell measured by EIS in a 0.5MHz–0.1Hz frequency range, signal amplitude of 10mV, collecting the data every day at 50°C. (B) Anodic stability window using three-electrode cell with Li as the counter and reference electrode, and Super P coated Al as the working electrode. Scan rate of 0.1mVs−1, voltage range between the OCV and 4.5V vs. Li/Li+. (C) Current vs. time profile upon application of 30mV DC signal to a symmetrical Li/Li cell used for the lithium transference number determination by Bruce-Vincent method (see experimental section for details). Inset: An impedance analysis performed immediately before, and after the application of 30mV DC signal. Temperature 50°C.
(A) Galvanostatic voltage profiles, and (B) cycling response of the Li/PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO/LiFePO4 cell. Current rate C/10 (1C=0.665mAcm−2). Voltage range 3.0–4.0V. Temperature 50°C.

head.ce:title: A novel polymer electrolyte membrane for application in solid state lithium metal battery

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Polyethylene oxide (PEO), dimethyl sulphoxide (DMSO) and lithium trifluoromethanesulfonate (LiCF3SO3) salts are combined into a composite polymer electrolyte studied for application in lithium metal battery. FTIR measurements and AFM images are used to reveal the structure and morphology of the polymer electrolyte, while electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), chronoamperometry and voltammetry are employed for determining the electrolyte conductivity, lithium transference number, chemical and electrochemical stability, respectively. The data reveal a suitable conductivity and lithium transport, i.e., δ above 10−4 Scm−1 and tLi + about 0.5, at moderate temperature, which allow the use of the membrane and a LiFePO4 olivine cathode in an efficient lithium metal cell delivering a capacity of 130mAhg−1 at about 3.4V, and operating at 50°C. This relatively low operating temperature, the good electrochemical properties, and the polymer configuration of the PEO-DMSO-LiCF3SO3 membrane suggest it as a viable solution for application in high energy lithium metal battery.

ce:section.ce:para: Polymer electrolytes have been extensively investigated as promising candidates for solid state lithium battery due to their mechanical flexibility, and scalability to the thin-film conducting configuration [1]. Among these very interesting materials, polyethylene oxide (PEO) has attracted particular attention due to its suitability for dissolving various salts in a vast range of concentrations, in combination with nanometric ceramics [2] which allow relevant mechanical stability and enhance the ionic conductivity [3]. However, the suitability of PEO-based membranes at temperatures exceeding 65°C to allow amorphous state and proper ion conduction still hinders its large scale diffusion [4]. Indeed, PEO chains have an extended helical structure with repeating units in turns of the helix. The ether oxygen of the chains coordinates the cations and forms stable polymer-ion complexes, while the anions are dispersed within the polymer matrix [5]. Besides, the chains form thin crystalline plates which, in turn, are arranged in thin stacks, and finally into spherical crystals separated by an amorphous polymer phase. Generally, this semi-crystallinity covers about 60% of the PEO bulk at room temperature, while the amorphous elastomeric phase, which strongly favors the segmental motion and the efficient ion transport through polymer of the PEO-salt complexes, constitutes the remaining part [6]. The presence of extended crystalline regions within PEO-based electrolytes at the room temperature strongly limits the long-range diffusion of the ions, and lowers the ionic conductivity [7]. The ion transport and conductivity may be actually enhanced by increasing the ratio of the amorphous elastomeric state with respect to the crystalline one in the electrolyte adopting various approaches, including the abovementioned nanometric ceramic addition, to obtain the nanocomposite polymer electrolytes (NCPEs) [8], the use of Ionic Liquids (ILs) [9,10] as well as the employment of various solvents as plasticizer agents [11]. A very interesting approach consisted of the use of emulsifying agents such as DMSO, which forms thermodynamically stable DMSO/Li ion molecules [12,13]. However, the very poor SEI forming ability of DMSO‑lithium salt emulsions strongly limited their use as the electrolyte media in lithium cells [14]. Following this trend, we advantageously combined the mechanical and electrochemical stability features of the PEO, and the highly ion-conducting nature of the DMSO, in a new electrolyte studied for application in polymeric lithium metal battery. The electrolyte is fully characterized in terms of conductivity, ion transport characteristics, chemical and electrochemical stability, and employed in an efficient lithium metal battery using LiFePO4 electrode [15].

Linear PEO with a molecular weight of 600,000gmol−1 (Sigma Aldrich) and DMSO (Sigma Aldrich) in a proportion of 1.7g of PEO to 1.5ml of DMSO, and 0.3g of LiCF3SO3 (Sigma Aldrich, battery grade), were dissolved in acetonitrile (Sigma Aldrich, battery grade), stirred for 2h at a temperature of 60°C, transferred to glass petri dish and kept at 80°C overnight in an oven. The molar ratio of the Li in salt to oxygen in EO was 1:20, therefore the membrane is indicated in the work by PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO. The membrane was subsequently dried at 50°C for 5days under vacuum, in order to remove traces of water or solvent, and transferred to a glove box (M brown) with water and oxygen content lower than 1ppm. The final membrane (photographic image in Fig. 1 ) with a thickness of about 350μm was characterized by good mechanical stability. A control sample with the same composition, indicated by PEO20LiCF3SO3 was prepared following similar procedure without DMSO for comparison.

FTIR spectra of PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO and PEO20LiCF3SO3 were performed using an ATR-FTIR Perkin Elmer Spectrum 100 series, scanning in the range of 600–4000cm−1. Atomic force microscopy images were collected using a AFM JEOL JSM-7600F instrument. Conductivity measurements were performed on 2032 coin-cell with Teflon O-ring having internal diameter of 10 mm and thickness of 320μm to determine the cell constant, using a frequency analyzer Princeton Advanced Research (VersaSTAT3F) in 0.5MHz–0.1Hz frequency range with signal amplitude of 10mV. The conductivity data were collected every 5°, and every 2° near by the transition temperature during cooling and subsequent heating. Before cooling measurement, the cell was held at 80°C for at least 12 hours. Galvanostatic cycling was performed using a Maccor series 4000 battery test system on Li/PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO/LiFePO4 2032 coin-cell in the potential range of 3.0–4.0V at current rate of C/10 (1C was 0.665mAcm−2, as calculated with respect to the electrode geometric surface considering the LiFePO4 active mass, i.e., 4mgcm−2, and its theoretical capacity, i.e., 170mAhg−1) [15], at temperatures of 50°C. The Li/PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO interface stability was measured at 50°C by impedance spectroscopy using a VersaSTAT3F instument on symmetrical lithium/lithium 2032 coin-cell in 0.5MHz – 0.1Hz frequency range and signal amplitude of 10mV. Electrochemical stability window was determined by linear sweep voltammetry on three electrode cell using the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane as the electrolyte, Li as the counter and reference electrode, and Super P on Al as the working electrode, with a scan rate of 0.1mVs−1 and voltage ranging between the OCV and 4.5V, employing a VersaSTAT3F instrument. The lithium transference number was measured with the same instrument at 50°C by adopting the Bruce Vincent method which involved current monitoring during time upon the application of a 30mV direct-current (DC) signal to a symmetrical Li/PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO/Li cell until the steady state was reached, and impedance measurement immediately before, and after DC-current application [16].

Intermolecular interactions, and plasticizing effect of DMSO on PEO are investigated by FTIR measurements carried on the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO polymer electrolytes and reported in Fig. 2 . The figure shows a band at 844cm−1 (tagged by 1 in Fig. 2A and magnified in the top-left panel of Fig. 2B) assigned to the antisymmetric rocking mode of CH2-CH2 coupled with the COC symmetric stretching mode, a band at 963cm−1 (tagged by 2 in Fig. 2A and magnified in the top-right panel of Fig. 2B) primarily associated with the CH2 antisymmetric rocking mode with appreciable contribution of the COC antisymmetric stretching mode [17], a band at 1102cm−1 (tagged by 3 in Fig. 2A and magnified in the bottom-left panel of Fig. 2B) mainly associated with the COC antisymmetric stretching mode, and a band at 1345cm−l (tagged by 4 in Fig. 2A and magnified in the bottom-right panel of Fig. 2B) due to the hybridized mode of the CH2 antisymmetric wagging and twisting modes of the CH2 CH2 group of PEO. The lower wavenumber region provides information about the modifications in local structure of host polymer due to the interaction of DMSO with polymer backbone. The intensity decrease of the two characteristic bands at 844cm−1 and 963cm−1 in the composite electrolyte evidences a distortion of the helical configuration of PEO polymer backbone, due to the plasticizing effect of DMSO [18,19]. In addition, the shift of the bands at 1102 and 963cm−1 reveals a decrease of the OCCO torsional angle in the electrolyte with respect to pure PEO, as already demonstrated by ab initio calculations reported in literature [20], thus further suggesting the DMSO plasticizing effect on the PEO polymer matrix. The peak at 1042cm−1 in the case of DMSO (tagged by 5 in Fig. 2A) is due to SO vibrational stretching, which is shifted to 1030cm−1 in PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO, thus indicating the association of DMSO with PEO and/or Li ion. In addition, the peaks between 3000cm−1 to 2700cm−1 (tagged by 6 in Fig. 2A) are assigned to the CH stretching of the PEO backbone and the methyl of DMSO. The peak at 1466cm−1 (tagged by 7) is assigned to the CH deformation of the PEO backbone. In the spectrum of DMSO the peaks at 1436 and 1404cm−1 (tagged by 8) are assigned to the antisymmetric bending of CH3, while the peak at 1306cm−1 (tagged by 9) is assigned to symmetric deformation of CH3 group that are attached to the sulfur atom.

The plasticizing effect of DMSO on PEO matrix was further investigated by using an atomic force microscope (AFM). Fig. 3 shows the three dimensional topography images of PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane (A) and PEO20LiCF3SO3 blank (B). The images reveal smoother surface of PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO (Fig. 3A) compared to PEO20LiCF3SO3 (Fig. 3B), which is most likely due to the decrease of membrane tortuosity caused by the addition of the DMSO plasticizer. Indeed, the latter increases the ratio of the amorphous phase of the PEO matrix with respect to the crystalline one, thus facilitating the segmental rearrangement of polymer chain and, therefore, the ion movement [21].

Fig. 4 shows the Arrhenius conductivity plots of the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO electrolyte membrane during cooling from a temperature of about 80°C to 40°C (A) and heating back to about 80°C (B), as well as the steady state conductivities in a similar temperature interval of the PEO20LiCF3SO3 blank (indicated by stars in each panel). During cooling (Fig. 4A) the Arrhenius plot of the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO electrolyte exhibits the typical trend of the PEO-based polymer membranes, with slope change around 50°C corresponding to the conductivity decrease during the transition from amorphous to crystalline phase (generally to spherical crystalline stacks). Furthermore, the electrolyte reveals a higher conductivity with respect to the blank membrane (indicated by stars in the plot of Fig. 4A) over the whole range, and a lower value of amorphous- crystalline transition temperature (i.e., about 50°C instead of 65°C) [6]. The higher conductivity may be attributed to the abovementioned plasticizing effect of the DMSO which increases the amorphous region and limits the PEO chains reorganization into spherical crystalline stacks.

This important effect decreases the operating temperature of the PEO-based electrolyte, as indeed demonstrated by the electrochemical test reported below. Despite characterized by a higher conductivity with respect to the control, the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane shows some kinetic limit during heating back to the initial temperature (80°C) and the crystalline-amorphous transition shifts up to about 60°C (Fig. 4B). This phenomenon suggests the use of a proper thermal treatment for allowing the operation of cells employing PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane at the lower temperatures (e.g., 50°C). It is worth mentioning that the operating condition adopted for the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane preparation, including solvent removal by vacuum, leads to a solid and partially amorphous membrane, with a minor amount of liquid DMSO (<5%). In fact, DMSO boils at 189°C, and can be evaporated under vacuum system with sufficiently low pressure (1mbar in our system) which induces sufficient evaporation below 50°C. Therefore, DMSO is expected to act only as a plasticizer rather than a conducting or solvating agent for ions transport, which is indeed mainly driven by the amorphous chains of the PEO.

The difference between Fermi level of the electrode, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO), and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) levels of the electrolyte governs the thermodynamic stability of the electrolyte. Hence, negative electrodes with Fermi level higher in energy than the LUMO of the electrolyte, such as lithium metal with a redox potential as low as −3V vs. SHE, thermodynamically enable its electrochemical reduction [22]. However, the formation of a protecting layer coating the lithium surface, i.e. a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), due to direct chemical reaction of lithium and electrolyte, kinetically avoids further reduction and protects the metal surface [23,24]. This is clearly demonstrated in the case of the PEO20LiCF3SO3 DMSO electrolyte by analyzing the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) response of a Li/PEO20LiCF3SO3 DMSO/Li cell, stored under open circuit conditions and 50°C. Fig. 5A, reporting the interfacial resistance of the symmetric cell obtained by EIS, reveals an initial increase of the resistance, due to the abovementioned chemical reaction of lithium and electrolyte, and the subsequent stabilization of the interface resistance upon six days due to the formation and structural stabilization of the SEI film [25]. On the other hand, HOMO levels of PEO-based electrolytes are largely exceeded by the fermi levels of several cathodes operating over 4V, such as transition metal layered oxides, and metal phosphates using Mn, and Co [26], which may oxidize and degrade the electrolyte, while LiFePO4, operating at 3.5V [15] is actually suitable for PEO-based lithium ion conducting membranes [27]. The stability of the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO electrolyte against oxidation is determined by linear sweep voltammetry of a three electrode cell using the membrane as the electrolyte, lithium metal as the counter and reference electrode, and carbon casted Al as the working electrode (Fig. 5B). Although stainless-steel may be adopted for this kind of measurement, the choice of carbon cast on Al using a PVDF binder appears here to be more appropriate since this configuration well simulates a practical cathode film [28]. Fig. 5B reveals complete electrolyte oxidative decomposition at a potential value higher than 4.1V vs. Li+/Li, which is higher than the one ascribed to pure PEO (3.9V vs. Li+/Li) as most likely due to a stabilizing action of the DMSO [29]. Furthermore, negligible oxidation peak observed around 3.4V Li+/Li may be attributed to water or solvent traces not completely removed during preparation. The electrochemical stability window of the electrolyte, and the formation of suitable SEI layer at the electrodes, may actually allow its safe and efficient employment in lithium battery using lithium iron phosphate (LiFePO4) which operates at about 3.5V Li+/Li [30,31].

An important parameter for allowing a proper operation of the membrane in cell, is the lithium transference number (tLi+), i.e., the fraction of charge driven by lithium ions during current flowing, which is calculated in this work by Bruce-Evans-Vincent method using chronoamperometry and EIS, performed on a symmetrical Li/PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO/Li cell (see experimental section for details) and the Eq. (1) [16]:
(1)

where I0 is the initial current, Iss the steady state current, ΔV the applied voltage and R0 and Rss are resistances before and after DC polarization; respectively.

The values of the initial current, steady state current and impedance of the cell as assembled, and after the DC polarizations, are reported in Fig. 5C (and EIS in inset) for the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane at 50°C. The application of the Bruce-Evans-Vincent Eq. (1) using the data of Fig. 5 allows the determination of a tLi + of 0.5, which exceeds the one ascribed to the PEO control electrolyte (i.e., 0.3 to 0.4), calculated through the same method. The reason for higher transference number of PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane with respect to bare PEO is the favored ion transport through polymer segments of the amorphous phase of PEO-salt complexes, which is promoted by the plasticizing effect of DMSO [32]. Indeed, the amorphous phase of the electrolyte increases the ion transport by enhancing their long-range diffusion, while, as already mentioned above, we may likely exclude the direct role of free DMSO molecules in solvating the lithium ions.

The performances of the new PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO polymer electrolyte in a rechargeable lithium metal cell using a LiFePO4 olivine cathode at a current of C/10 (1C=170mAg−1) and a temperature of 50°C are reported in Fig. 6 . The voltage vs. specific capacity of the cell shown in Fig. 6A revels the typical plateau, evolving around 3.4V, due the Li-ion insertion and de-insertion in the LiFePO4 olivine structure [33]. The figure reveals during the first cycle a low efficiency due to the irreversible process ascribed to the decomposition of the electrolyte, with formation of a protective SEI film on the electrodes surface and rearrangement of the electrode structure. Subsequently, the cycling trend of Fig. 6B shows an efficiency approaching 100%, an initial specific capacity of the order of 140mAhg−1 (i.e., 83% of the theoretical value) and a steady state capacity of about 125mAhg−1. However, during the final cycling stages the cell polarization between charge and discharge increases, and the capacity decreases to about 100 mAhrg−1 by 40cycles. Despite the cycling trend of Fig. 6 that demonstrates the suitability of the electrolyte for battery application, it also reveals issues of the long terms stability. These issue may be most likely ascribed to irregular SEI formation and growth due to partial electrolyte reactivity and possible presence of impurities, as indeed suggested by the additional voltammetry peak observed in Fig. 5B at about 3.4V, and to possible loss of DMSO during cycling with consequent decrease of the electrolyte performances. The same finding was observed by Liu et al., in an in situ AFM investigation of SEI in DMSO-based electrolyte. Indeed, lithium ions solvated by DMSO may easily intercalate into graphite layers, leading to serious decomposition and structural deterioration of the SEI [34]. The electrolyte performances may be actually further improved by the addition of ceramic fillers, such as nanometric silica (SiO2) or alumina (Al2O3), preferably silane-treated, as indeed demonstrated by our previous works [32]. The addition of ceramic fillers to the polymer electrolyte which absorbs and incorporates impurities may, in fact, lead to stable, compact and thin passivation layer, thus remarkably increasing the cycle life of the cell [35]. Furthermore, the development of electrolytes added by redox species [36], multilayer hybrid electrolytes [37] for lithium ion battery, as well as the use of free-standing membranes for advanced applications such as Li/S cells [38], may actually be suitable for achieving new generation of energy storage systems. We may point out, however, that the relatively low operating temperature, i.e., 50°C, suggests the polymer electrolyte herein studied as a suitable media for a safe solid lithium metal battery.

A solid polymer electrolyte, composed of PEO, DMSO, and LiCF3SO3, with favorable mechanical properties, has been studied for application in high energy lithium metal battery. FTIR revealed that the local structure of host PEO polymer is modified due to the plasticizing effect of DMSO. Arrhenius conductivity plots of the electrolyte exhibited the typical characteristics of PEO-based electrolyte, however with an amorphous to crystalline phase transition lowered to 50°C instead of 65°C of the control membrane. Furthermore, the electrolyte revealed a lithium transference number (tLi +) as high as 0.5, rather than 0.3–0.4 ascribed to the DMSO-free electrolyte. These notable improvements were attributed to the plasticizing effect of the DMSO into the membrane. The electrolyte revealed a stability extending over 4.1V vs. Li+/Li, however it has also shown side peak at the lower voltage due to possible presence of impurities which compromised the long-term cycling stability. The PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO polymer electrolyte allowed the efficient operation of a lithium metal battery with a solid state configuration using the LiFePO4 olivine cathode. Solid PEO-based membranes are generally used in lithium cell at temperature higher than 70°C, as their conductivity allows efficient operation only at the abovementioned condition. The plasticizing effect of DMSO in the PEO20LiCF3SO3DMSO membrane herein studied allowed higher conductivity at lower temperature, and proper cell operation above 50°C. The cell revealed a voltage about 3.4V and a capacity of about 120mAhg−1, at the relatively low temperature of 50°C, thus suggesting the suitability of membrane herein studied for battery application.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: B.W. acknowledges HNF facility at Howard University for AFM imaging. J.H. thanks University of Ferrara for the grant “Fondo di Ateneo per la Ricerca Locale FAR 2016” and the collaboration project “Accordo di Collaborazione Quadro 2015” between University of Ferrara (Department of Chemical and Pharmaceutical Sciences) and Sapienza University of Rome (Department of Chemistry).
